update.description:
This addresses several of @\_jrivero_ 's comments about pull request #891 (refactoring of SurfaceParams), which was recently merged. Additionally, I created a class in SurfaceParams to store the mu1 and mu2 variables, which are common to ODE and Bullet (maybe dart as well). This allows the bounds checking to be done in a single place.

I would classify this pull request as refactoring (similar to pull request #891). It's still on the todo list to make a test for the fdir1 parameter (#630) and fix friction for the other physics engines (#989, #1000).
update.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

content.raw:
I've implemented a simpler API in 19794e4 with a slight modification:

* GetMuPrimary()
* GetMuSecondary()
* SetMuPrimary(value)
* SetMuSecondary(value)

Rebuilding to verify that I didn't make any typos.
content.html:
I've implemented a simpler API in 19794e4 with a slight modification:

  • GetMuPrimary()
  • GetMuSecondary()
  • SetMuPrimary(value)
  • SetMuSecondary(value)

Rebuilding to verify that I didn't make any typos.

content.raw: It'll be easier to change the API now than later, so let's figure out what we want. Is there consensus that Carlos's suggestion for the public-facing API is preferable (assuming that it's implemented as Nate suggested)?
content.html: It'll be easier to change the API now than later, so let's figure out what we want. Is there consensus that Carlos's suggestion for the public-facing API is preferable (assuming that it's implemented as Nate suggested)?

pullrequest.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

content.raw:
There is a middle ground. The GetPrimary/Secondary functions could be the public API, which in turn call the private accessor and mutators that use index values.

This would have a nice public API without duplicate code.

Just something to consider, I'm not trying to force this.
content.html:
There is a middle ground. The GetPrimary/Secondary functions could be the public API, which in turn call the private accessor and mutators that use index values.

This would have a nice public API without duplicate code.

Just something to consider, I'm not trying to force this.

content.raw: I did a similar thing when I first implemented it, but I decided that checking for 0 or 1 was better than having duplicated code. What if I make an enum like [UniversalJoint::AXIS_INDEX](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/c15e727be86699f3293a8f9e6745227d936e3387/gazebo/physics/UniversalJoint.hh?at=default#cl-42)?
content.html: I did a similar thing when I first implemented it, but I decided that checking for 0 or 1 was better than having duplicated code. What if I make an enum like UniversalJoint::AXIS_INDEX?

pull_request.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

pullrequest.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

content.raw:
Currently the `FrictionPyramid` class is instantiated directly in `ODESurfaceParams` and `BulletSurfaceParams`. Additionally, the friction values aren't typically known until `Load` is called, which is long after Construction.

I thought about implementing this very thing, but I wasn't sure the workflow for which it would be used, and I didn't want to add code that doesn't actually get used.
content.html:
Currently the FrictionPyramid class is instantiated directly in ODESurfaceParams and BulletSurfaceParams. Additionally, the friction values aren't typically known until Load is called, which is long after Construction.

I thought about implementing this very thing, but I wasn't sure the workflow for which it would be used, and I didn't want to add code that doesn't actually get used.

pull_request.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

pullrequest.title: Create FrictionPyramid class to generalize mu1, mu2, and fdir1 parameters

content.raw:
In my humble opinion I would create something in the line of:

* GetPrimaryMu()
* GetSecondaryMu()
* SetPrimaryMy(value)
* SetSecondaryMu(value)

I believe it's more readable and less prone to errors than using a 0 or 1 to specify the direction. If there are only two options (primary, secondary), is not a big deal to create two additional methods. As a bonus you can get rid of the extra check that you're doing to make sure the index is 0 or 1.
content.html:
In my humble opinion I would create something in the line of:

  • GetPrimaryMu()
  • GetSecondaryMu()
  • SetPrimaryMy(value)
  • SetSecondaryMu(value)

I believe it's more readable and less prone to errors than using a 0 or 1 to specify the direction. If there are only two options (primary, secondary), is not a big deal to create two additional methods. As a bonus you can get rid of the extra check that you're doing to make sure the index is 0 or 1.
